author: gcolvin
content: <@301186049323958275> "Reference Implementation" implies an implementation that meets the spec so well that it can serve as a spec in it's own right.  In the (I think common) case where the spec has been refined from one or more existing implementations none of them may meet the spec, but all may be useful as evidence that the facility being specified is useful, and to help reviewers to understand the spec.  But yes, I bit more explanation than a bare link is appropriate.

author: sky.cactus
content: I would be fine if reference implementation is required to meet the spec strictly.

author: sky.cactus
content: What I really want is a way to reduce external links in EIPs.  I think external links should live elsewhere, not in the specification.

author: sky.cactus
content: The spec for email addresses, doesn't contain a link out to where someone implemented an email parser, it either has an inline parser or none at all.

author: gcolvin
content: I hear you, but it's a very good thing for specs to codify existing practice.  For all but small proposals the implementations will  be too large to be placed in the spec.

author: gcolvin
content:
> I generally don't think there is value in including links to external implementations, but that is the only pragmatic way to fill in that section.  ...  If they inline the code, then it is a reference implementation, which is why I thought renaming the section would help.
<@!301186049323958275> This is where I think we disagree.  I see lots of value in implementations of a spec.  Many implementations will be too large to inline, 
 so references are the only way to include them.   And being inlined is not what makes something a reference implementation.

One tension seems to be that an EIP is both a proposed improvement and an argument for why it is an improvement, and such arguments may need to supporting external references.   A general solution might be to pick a standard format for references in an EIP, including links, and clarify their appropriate use.

author: axic3354
content:
> A general solution might be to pick a standard format for references in an EIP, including links, and clarify their appropriate use.

<@!683653554631868440> this might be a useful step in any case, requiring properly formatted references instead of links makes it more likely that even in the case of a dead link the reference could be found.

author: sky.cactus
content:
> an argument for why it is an improvement, and such arguments may need to supporting external references. 
<@!683653554631868440> Ah, I feel pretty strongly that EIPs **SHOULD NOT** be an argument, it should only be a technical spec.  The argument for why should happen elsewhere.  I *do* support a motivation section, but mainly just for historical purposes and it more or less just says, "here are some use cases and/or why this is a good thing" but not a formal argument.

author: gcolvin
content: It's a matter of balance and taste, <@!301186049323958275>.
